function.api-description: Executes a call to the Ruckig online trajectory generator. The Ruckig online trajectory generator provides instantaneous trajectory generation capabilities for motion control systems. This function prepares a position-based trajectory generation object, that can then be calculated with sim.ruckigStep. When this object is not needed anymore, remove it with sim.ruckigRemove

ul.li: dofs: number of degrees of freedom (n).
baseCycleTime: smallest expected cycle time. The cycle time should always be a multiple of baseCycleTime. Use a value of 0.0001 (0.1ms).
flags: Ruckig flags. -1 for default flags.
currentPos: current position (one value for each DoF)
currentVel: current velocity (one value for each DoF)
currentAccel: current acceleration (one value for each DoF)
maxVel: maximum allowed velocity (one value for each DoF, i.e. [maxV_1 ... maxV_n]). If sim.ruckig_minvel is specified in flags, then maxVel should contain [maxV_1 ... maxV_n minV_1 ... minV_n]

maxAccel: maximum allowed acceleration (one value for each DoF, i.e. [maxA_1 ... maxA_n]). If sim.ruckig_minaccel is specified in flags, then maxAccel should contain [maxA_1 ... maxA_n minA_1 ... minA_n]
maxJerk: maximum allowed jerk (one value for each DoF)
selection: selection vector (one value for each DoF). For a default behaviour, fill the vector with non-zero values.
targetPos: target position (one value for each DoF)
targetVel: target velocity (one value for each DoF)
reserved1: reserved. Set to nullptr
reserved2: reserved. Set to nullptr
A negative value in case of an error, otherwise the handle of the created object

function.api-synopsis-python: int handle = sim.ruckigPos(int dofs, float baseCycleTime, int flags, list currentPosVelAccel, list maxVelAccelJerk, list selection, list targetPosVel)
function.api-synopsis-lua: int handle = sim.ruckigPos(int dofs, float baseCycleTime, int flags, float[] currentPosVelAccel, float[] maxVelAccelJerk, int[] selection, float[] targetPosVel)

ul.li: dofs: number of degrees of freedom (n).
baseCycleTime: smallest expected cycle time. The cycle time should always be a multiple of baseCycleTime. Use a value of 0.0001 (0.1ms).
flags: Ruckig flags. -1 for default flags.
currentPosVelAccel: current position, velocity and acceleration: [pos_1 ... pos_n vel_1 ... vel_n accel_1 ... accel_n] (one value for each DoF)

maxVelAccelJerk: maximum allowed velocity, acceleration and jerk: [maxV_1 ... maxV_n maxA_1 ... maxA_n maxJ_1 ... maxJ_n]. If sim.ruckig_minvel is specified in flags, then maxVelAccelJerk should contain following additional values: [minV_1 ... minV_n]. If sim.ruckig_minaccel is specified in flags, then maxVelAccelJerk should contain following additional values: [minA_1 ... minA_n]
selection: selection vector (one value for each DoF). For a default behaviour, fill the vector with non-zero values.
targetPosVel: target position and velocity: [tPos_1 ... tPos_n tVel_1 ... tVel_n]
handle: the handle to the created object

function.api-calltip: int handle = sim.ruckigPos(int dofs, float baseCycleTime, int flags, float[] currentPosVelAccel, float[] maxVelAccelJerk, int[] selection, float[] targetPosVel)

function.api-description: Removes an object previously created via sim.ruckigPos or sim.ruckigVel.
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simRuckigRemove(int handle)

ul.li: handle: handle of the object created via simRuckigPos or simRuckigVel.
1 in case of success

function.api-synopsis-python: sim.ruckigRemove(int handle)
function.api-synopsis-lua: sim.ruckigRemove(int handle)

ul.li: handle: handle of the object created via sim.ruckigPos or sim.ruckigVel.

function.api-calltip: sim.ruckigRemove(int handle)

function.api-description: Executes a call to the Ruckig online trajectory generator. The Ruckig online trajectory generator provides instantaneous trajectory generation capabilities for motion control systems. This function steps forward a trajectory generation algorithm previously prepared via sim.ruckigPos or sim.ruckigVel
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simRuckigStep(int handle, double cycleTime, double* newPos, double* newVel, double* newAccel, double* syncTime, double* reserved1, int* reserved2)

ul.li: handle: handle of the object created via simRuckigPos or simRuckigVel.
cycleTime: cycle time or simulation step. Should always be a multiple of the base cycle time
newPos: new position
newVel: new velocity
newAccel: new acceleration
syncTime: synchronization time (output). This is the time needed to reach the desired state. This time does not include the cycle time of the current call to sim.RuckigStep)
reserved1: reserved. Set to nullptr
reserved2: reserved. Set to nullptr

-1 or -2 in case of an immediate error, otherwise the return value of the update function in the motion library:
1: Finished (final state reached)
0: Working (final state not yet reached)
-100: ErrorInvalidInput
-101: ErrorTrajectoryDuration
-110: ErrorExecutionTimeCalculation
-111: ErrorSynchronizationCalculation

function.api-synopsis-python: int result, list newPosVelAccel, float synchronizationTime = sim.ruckigStep(int handle, float cycleTime)
function.api-synopsis-lua: int result, float[] newPosVelAccel, float synchronizationTime = sim.ruckigStep(int handle, float cycleTime)

ul.li: handle: handle of the object created via sim.ruckigPos or sim.ruckigVel.
cycleTime: cycle time or simulation step. Should always be a multiple of the base cycle time

result: return value of the update function in the motion library:
1: Result::Finished (final state reached)
0: Result::Working (final state not yet reached)
-100: Result::ErrorInvalidInput
-101: Result::ErrorTrajectoryDuration
-110: Result::ErrorExecutionTimeCalculation
-111: Result::ErrorSynchronizationCalculation
newPosVelAccel: new positions, velocities and accelerations, i.e. [p0 ... pn v0 ... vn a0 ... an]

function.api-calltip: int result, float[] newPosVelAccel, float synchronizationTime = sim.ruckigStep(int handle, float cycleTime)

function.api-description: Executes a call to the Ruckig online trajectory generator. The Ruckig online trajectory generator provides instantaneous trajectory generation capabilities for motion control systems. This function prepares a velocity-based trajectory generation object, that can then be calculated with sim.ruckigStep. When this object is not needed anymore, remove it with sim.ruckigRemove

ul.li: dofs: number of degrees of freedom (n).
baseCycleTime: smallest expected cycle time. The cycle time should always be a multiple of baseCycleTime. Use a value of 0.0001 (0.1ms).
flags: Ruckig flags. -1 for default flags.
currentPos: current position (one value for each DoF)
currentVel: current velocity (one value for each DoF)
currentAccel: current acceleration (one value for each DoF)

maxAccel: maximum allowed acceleration (one value for each DoF, i.e. [maxA_1 ... maxA_n]). If sim.ruckig_minaccel is specified in flags, then maxAccel should contain [maxA_1 ... maxA_n minA_1 ... minA_n]
maxJerk: maximum allowed jerk (one value for each DoF)
selection: selection vector (one value for each DoF). For a default behaviour, fill the vector with non-zero values.
targetVel: target velocity (one value for each DoF)
reserved1: reserved. Set to nullptr
reserved2: reserved. Set to nullptr
A negative value in case of an error, otherwise the handle of the created object

function.api-synopsis-python: int handle = sim.ruckigVel(int dofs, float baseCycleTime, int flags, list currentPosVelAccel, list maxAccelJerk, list selection, list targetVel)
function.api-synopsis-lua: int handle = sim.ruckigVel(int dofs, float baseCycleTime, int flags, float[] currentPosVelAccel, float[] maxAccelJerk, int[] selection, float[] targetVel)

ul.li: dofs: number of degrees of freedom (n).
baseCycleTime: smallest expected cycle time. The cycle time should always be a multiple of baseCycleTime. Use a value of 0.0001 (0.1ms).
flags: Ruckig flags. -1 for default flags.
currentPosVelAccel: current position, velocity and acceleration: [pos_1 ... pos_n vel_1 ... vel_n accel_1 ... accel_n] (one value for each DoF)

maxAccelJerk: maximum allowed acceleration and jerk: [maxA_1 ... maxA_n maxJ_1 ... maxJ_n]. If sim.ruckig_minaccel is specified in flags, then maxAccelJerk should contain following additional values: [minA_1 ... minA_n]
selection: selection vector (one value for each DoF). For a default behaviour, fill the vector with non-zero values.
targetVel: target velocity (one value for each DoF)
handle: the handle of the created object

function.api-calltip: int handle = sim.ruckigVel(int dofs, float baseCycleTime, int flags, float[] currentPosVelAccel, float[] maxAccelJerk, int[] selection, float[] targetVel)

function.api-description: Saves an image to file or to memory
function.api-synopsis-cpp: simSaveImage(const unsigned char* image, const int* resolution, int options, const char* filename, int quality, void* reserved)

ul.li: image: a pointer to rgb, rgba or greyscale values.
resolution: the x/y resolution of the provided image.
options: bit-coded. If bit0 and bit1 represent the format of the provided image (0=rgb, 1=rgba, 2=greyscale).
filename: the name of the file to write. The file extension indicates the format.
quality: the quality of the written image: 0 for best compression, 100 for largest file. Use -1 for default behaviour.
reserved: Reserved for future extension. Set to nullptr.
-1 if operation was not successful.

function.api-synopsis-python: bytes imgBuffer = sim.saveImage(bytes image, list resolution, int options, string filename, int quality)
function.api-synopsis-lua: buffer imgBuffer = sim.saveImage(buffer image, int[2] resolution, int options, string filename, int quality)

ul.li: image: image (in rgb, rgba or greyscale format)
resolution: x/y resolution of the provided image.

options: bit-coded:
bit0 - bit1: format of the provided image (0=rgb, 1=rgba, 2=greyscale)
filename: name of the file to write. The file extension indicates the format. If the filename only contains '.ext', where ext represents the file format, then the image will be saved to memory
quality: quality of the written image: 0 for best compression, 100 for largest file. Use -1 for default behaviour.
imgBuffer: a buffer containing the image in packed format (e.g. png, jpg, etc.), if the image was specified to be saved to memory.

function.api-calltip: buffer serializedImage = sim.saveImage(buffer image, int[2] resolution, int options, string filename, int quality)

function.api-description: Opens a serial port (RS-232) for communication. When called from a script, the function can only be called when the simulation is running (and in that case the port is automatically closed at simulation stop)
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simSerialOpen(char* portString, int baudRate, void* reserved1, void* reserved2)

ul.li: portString: string specifying the port to open. Under Windows, use something similar to "\\.\COM1". Under MacOS and Linux, use something similar to "/dev/*" (check the "/dev" folder to know what file to specify). Under Linux, you might have to launch CoppeliaSim with super user priviledges in order to access the serial port.
baudRate: baudrate
reserved1: reserved for future extension. Keep at nullptr.
reserved2: reserved for future extension. Keep at nullptr.
-1 if operation was not successful, otherwise a port handle

function.api-synopsis-lua: int result = sim.serialOpen(string portString, int baudRate)

ul.li: portString: string specifying the port to open. Under Windows, use something similar to "\\.\COM1". Under MacOS and Linux, use something similar to "/dev/*" (check the "/dev" folder to know what file to specify). Under Linux, you might have to launch CoppeliaSim with super user priviledges in order to access the serial port
baudRate: baudrate
result: the port handle

function.api-calltip: int portHandle = sim.serialOpen(string portString, int baudrate)

function.api-description: Reads from a previously opened serial port (RS-232). The C version of the function cannot be blocking
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simSerialRead(int portHandle, char* buffer, int dataLengthToRead)

ul.li: portHandle: handle returned by the simSerialOpen function
buffer: buffer that will be filled with read data
dataLengthToRead: maximum data length that should be read
-1 if operation was not successful, otherwise the effective data length that was read

function.api-synopsis-lua: string data = sim.serialRead(int portHandle, int dataLengthToRead, bool blockingOperation, string closingString = '', float timeout = 0)

ul.li: portHandle: handle returned by the sim.serialOpen function
dataLengthToRead: maximum data length that should be read

blockingOperation: if true and the calling script is running in a thread, then the function only returns when the desired data length was read (or if the closingString was met, or if there was a timeout (see next arguments)

closingString: string (containing any byte value) can be specified, that will break from the blocking operation if a match was found in the incoming data. Useful when you know that a data packet is always ended with a given signature. Can be an empty string for default operation.
timeout: duration after which the blocking operation will be aborted, or 0 if the timeout is infinite
data: a string containing read data (excluding the closingString if it was specified and found)

function.api-calltip: buffer data = sim.serialRead(int portHandle, int dataLengthToRead, bool blockingOperation, buffer closingString='', float timeout=0)

ul.li: portHandle: handle returned by the simSerialOpen function

dataLength: length of the data to be sent
-1 if operation was not successful, otherwise the effective data length that was written

function.api-synopsis-lua: int charsSent = sim.serialSend(int portHandle, buffer data)

ul.li: portHandle: handle returned by the sim.serialOpen function
data: pointer to the data that should be sent
charsSent: the effective data length that was written

function.api-description: Sets the transformation matrix of an object. Dynamically simulated objects, together with their hierarchy tree, are dynamically reset (this however does not apply to static shapes)
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simSetObjectMatrix(int objectHandle, int relativeToObjectHandle, const double* matrix)

ul.li: objectHandle: handle of the object. Can be combined with sim.handleflag_reljointbaseframe

relativeToObjectHandle: indicates relative to which reference frame the matrix is specified. Specify sim.handle_world to set the absolute transformation matrix, sim.handle_inverse to set the inverse of the absolute transformation matrix, sim.handle_parent to set the transformation matrix relative to the object's parent, or an object handle relative to whose reference frame the transformation matrix is specified. If this handle is the handle of a joint, then the matrix is applied relative to the joint's moving frame (unless objectHandle is combined with sim.handleflag_reljointbaseframe, in which case the matrix is applied relative to the joint's base frame)
matrix: the matrix (array of 12 values [Vx0 Vy0 Vz0 P0 Vx1 Vy1 Vz1 P1 Vx2 Vy2 Vz2 P2])
-1 if operation was not successful

function.api-synopsis-python: sim.setObjectMatrix(int objectHandle, list matrix, int relativeToObjectHandle = sim.handle_world)
function.api-synopsis-lua: sim.setObjectMatrix(int objectHandle, float[12] matrix, int relativeToObjectHandle = sim.handle_world)

ul.li: objectHandle: handle of the object. Can be combined with sim.handleflag_reljointbaseframe
matrix: the matrix (array of 12 values [Vx0 Vy0 Vz0 P0 Vx1 Vy1 Vz1 P1 Vx2 Vy2 Vz2 P2])

relativeToObjectHandle: indicates relative to which reference frame the matrix is specified. Specify sim.handle_world to set the absolute transformation matrix, sim.handle_inverse to set the inverse of the absolute transformation matrix, sim.handle_parent to set the transformation matrix relative to the object's parent, or an object handle relative to whose reference frame the transformation matrix is specified. If this handle is the handle of a joint, then the matrix is applied relative to the joint's moving frame (unless objectHandle is combined with sim.handleflag_reljointbaseframe, in which case the matrix is applied relative to the joint's base frame)

function.api-calltip: sim.setObjectMatrix(int objectHandle, float[12] matrix, int relativeToObjectHandle = sim.handle_world)

function.api-description: Sets an object's parent object. Dynamically simulated objects, together with their hierarchy tree, are dynamically reset (this however does not apply to static shapes)
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simSetObjectParent(int objectHandle, int parentObjectHandle, bool keepInPlace)

ul.li: objectHandle: handle of the object that will become child of the parent object. Can be or-combined with sim_handleflag_assembly if an assembly operation is desired instead (in that case, parentObjectHandle can't be -1, and keepInPlace should be set to false)

parentObjectHandle: handle of the object that will become parent, or -1 if the object should become parentless. In an assembly operation, the assembly dummy on the parent object should be specified instead
keepInPlace: indicates whether the object's absolute pose should stay same
-1 if operation was not successful

keepInPlace: indicates whether the object's absolute pose should stay same

function.api-description: Sets various properties of a point cloud
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simSetPointCloudOptions(int pointCloudHandle, double maxVoxelSize, int maxPtCntPerVoxel, int options, double pointSize, void* reserved)

ul.li: pointCloudHandle: handle of the point cloud
maxVoxelSize: maximum size of the OC tree voxels containing points
maxPtCntPerVoxel: maximum number of points allowed in a same OC tree voxel

options: bit-coded:
bit0 set (1): points have random colors
bit1 set (2): show OC tree structure
bit2 set (4): reserved. keep unset
bit3 set (8): do not use an OC tree structure. When enabled, point cloud operations are limited, and point clouds will not be collidable, measurable or detectable anymore, but adding points will be much faster
bit4 set (16): color is emissive
pointSize: size of the points, in pixels
reserved: reserved for future extensions. Set to nullptr
1 if operation was successful

function.api-synopsis-python: sim.setPointCloudOptions(int pcHandle, float maxVoxelSize, int maxPtCntPerVoxel, int options, float pointSize)
function.api-synopsis-lua: sim.setPointCloudOptions(int pcHandle, float maxVoxelSize, int maxPtCntPerVoxel, int options, float pointSize)

ul.li: pcHandle: handle of the point cloud
maxVoxelSize: maximum size of the OC tree voxels containing points
maxPtCntPerVoxel: maximum number of points allowed in a same OC tree voxel

options: bit-coded:
bit0 set (1): points have random colors
bit1 set (2): show OC tree structure
bit2 set (4): reserved. keep unset
bit3 set (8): do not use an OC tree structure. When enabled, point cloud operations are limited, and point clouds will not be collidable, measurable or detectable anymore, but adding points will be much faster
bit4 set (16): color is emissive
pointSize: size of the points, in pixels

function.api-calltip: sim.setPointCloudOptions(int pointCloudHandle, float maxVoxelSize, int maxPtCntPerVoxel, int options, float pointSize)

function.api-description: Attaches a list of custom handles to a given scene object. Those custom handles are handles of other scene objects, that are linked to the given scene object (for whatever purpose). The advantage of storing references to other objects with this function is that CoppeliaSim will take care of correctly adjusting the references if needed: For instance, imagine objectA storing the handle of objectB via this function. If objectB is deleted, then the stored handle becomes -1. If objectA and objectB are duplicated at the same time, then the duplicate of objectA stores the handle of the duplicate of objectB. Optionally, if sim.handleflag_keeporiginal is specified, then linking to original objects is guaranteed, e.g. in above example, after a duplication of objectA, the duplicate of objectA will store the handle of the original objectB (if objectB still exists)
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simSetReferencedHandles(int objectHandle, int count, const int* referencedHandles, const char* tag, const int* reserved)

ul.li: objectHandle: handle of the scene object that will store the list of handles. Can be optionally combined with sim.handleflag_keeporiginal, in which case the handles that link to originals are retrieved
count: number of handles to store
referencedHandles: list of scene object handles.
tag: a tag: handles will be stored under this tag. nullptr defaults to an empty tag
reserved: reserved for future extensions
-1 in case of an error.

function.api-synopsis-python: sim.setReferencedHandles(int objectHandle, list referencedHandles, string tag = '')
function.api-synopsis-lua: sim.setReferencedHandles(int objectHandle, int[] referencedHandles, string tag = '')

ul.li: objectHandle: handle of the scene object that will store the list of handles. Can be optionally combined with sim.handleflag_keeporiginal, in which case the handles that link to originals are retrieved
referencedHandles: list of scene object handles.
tag: a tag: handles will be stored under this tag. Defaults to an empty tag

function.api-calltip: sim.setReferencedHandles(int objectHandle, int[] referencedHandles, string tag = '')

colorComponent: color component
rgbData: red, green and blue components of the color (3 values), or the transparency value (1 value)

function.api-description: Applies a new inertia matrix to a shape. If simulation is running, the shape is dynamically reset (similar to calling sim.resetDynamicObject right after)
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simSetShapeInertia(int shapeHandle, const double* inertiaMatrix, const double* transformationMatrix)

ul.li: shapeHandle: handle of the shape object
inertiaMatrix: new inertia matrix (9 values), expressed relative to transformationMatrix (itself expressed relative to the shape's reference frame)

transformationMatrix: a transformation matrix (array of 12 values [Vx0 Vy0 Vz0 P0 Vx1 Vy1 Vz1 P1 Vx2 Vy2 Vz2 P2]) expressed relative to the shape's reference frame. The matrix indicates the center of mass of the shape, and is the frame relative to which inertiaMatrix is expressed
-1 in case of an error

function.api-synopsis-python: sim.setShapeInertia(int shapeHandle, list inertiaMatrix, list transformationMatrix)
function.api-synopsis-lua: sim.setShapeInertia(int shapeHandle, float[9] inertiaMatrix, float[12] transformationMatrix)

ul.li: shapeHandle: handle of the shape object
inertiaMatrix: new inertia matrix (9 values), expressed relative to transformationMatrix (itself expressed relative to the shape's reference frame)

transformationMatrix: a transformation matrix (array of 12 values [Vx0 Vy0 Vz0 P0 Vx1 Vy1 Vz1 P1 Vx2 Vy2 Vz2 P2]) expressed relative to the shape's reference frame. The matrix indicates the center of mass of the shape, and is the frame relative to which inertiaMatrix is expressed

function.api-calltip: sim.setShapeInertia(int shapeHandle, float[9] inertiaMatrix, float[12] transformationMatrix)

function.api-description: Applies/removes a texture to/from a shape
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simSetShapeTexture(int h, int tId, int mode, int opt, const double* uvScaling, const double* pos, const double* orient)

ul.li: h: handle of the shape.
tId: ID of the texture or -1 to remove any existing texture. See also simGetTextureId, simGetShapeTextureId and simCreateTexture.
mode: texture mapping mode.

opt: bit-coded:
bit0: if set (1), then adjacent texture pixels are not interpolated.
bit1: if set (2), then the texture is applied as a decal (its appearance won't be influenced by light conditions).
bit2: if set (4), then the texture will be repeated along the U direction.
bit3: if set (8), then the texture will be repeated along the V direction.
uvScaling: pointer to 2 values that indicate the texture scaling factors along the U and V directions.
pos: pointer to 3 values (x,y,z) that indicate the texture position on the shape. Can be nullptr for default values.
orient: pointer to 3 values (Euler angles) that indicate the texture orientation on the shape. Can be nullptr for default values.
-1 in case of an error.

function.api-synopsis-python: sim.setShapeTexture(int shapeHandle, int textureId, int mappingMode, int options, list uvScaling, list position = None, list orientation = None)
function.api-synopsis-lua: sim.setShapeTexture(int shapeHandle, int textureId, int mappingMode, int options, float[2] uvScaling, float[3] position = nil, float[3] orientation = nil)

ul.li: shapeHandle: handle of the shape.
textureId: ID of the texture or -1 to remove any existing texture. See also sim.getTextureId, sim.getShapeTextureId and sim.createTexture
mappingMode: texture mapping mode.

options: bit-coded:
bit0: if set (1), then adjacent texture pixels are not interpolated.
bit1: if set (2), then the texture is applied as a decal (its appearance won't be influenced by light conditions).
bit2: if set (4), then the texture will be repeated along the U direction.
bit3: if set (8), then the texture will be repeated along the V direction.
uvScaling: array of 2 values indicating the texture scaling factors along the U and V directions
position: array of 3 values x/y/z indicating the texture position on the shape. Can be None/nil for default values
orientation: array of 3 values (Euler angles) indicating the texture orientation on the shape. Can be None/nil for default values

function.api-calltip: sim.setShapeTexture(int shapeHandle, int textureId, int mappingMode, int options, float[2] uvScaling, float[3] position=nil, float[3] orientation=nil)

function.api-description:
Enables or disables the stepping operation mode for a threaded script. If enabled, then the current script has to trigger each simulation step explicitly, via sim.step. Is applied cumulatively, i.e. if the stepping operation mode is enabled n times, it needs to be disabled n times to return to the initial state
(Lua specific: in stepping operation mode, automatic thread interruptions, i.e. preemptive threading, is supressed)
function.api-synopsis-python: int prevStepLevel = sim.setStepping(bool enable)
function.api-synopsis-lua: int prevStepLevel = sim.setStepping(bool enable / int desiredStepLevel)

ul.li: enable / desiredStepLevel: enable state, or the desired level of thread interruption
prevStepLevel: previous level of thread interruption. When 0, thread interruption was not enabled previously

function.api-calltip: int prevStepLevel = sim.setStepping(bool enabled)

function.api-description: Writes the image of a vision sensor (and applies any image processing via the vision callback functions). Make sure the vision sensor is flagged as external input
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simSetVisionSensorImg(int sensorHandle, const unsigned char* img, int options, const int* pos, const int* size)

ul.li: sensorHandle: handle of the vision sensor object
img: buffer containing the image

options: options, bit-coded:
bit0 set (1): the provided image is a greyscale image (1 byte per pixel), otherwise an RGB image (3 bytes per pixel)
bit1 set (2): the provided image has one additional byte per pixel, as alpha channel (RGBA or greyscale+A)
pos: position of the image portion to write. Can be nullptr, which defaults to [0 0]
size: size of the image portion to write. Can be nullptr which defaults to [0 0], which corresponds to [resolutionX resolutionY]
-1 if operation was not successful

function.api-synopsis-python: sim.setVisionSensorImg(int sensorHandle, bytes image, int options = 0, list pos = [0, 0], list size = [0, 0])
function.api-synopsis-lua: sim.setVisionSensorImg(int sensorHandle, buffer image, int options, int[2] pos = {0, 0}, int[2] size = {0, 0})

ul.li: sensorHandle: handle of the vision sensor object
img: buffer containing the image

options: options, bit-coded:
bit0 set (1): the provided image is a greyscale image (1 byte per pixel), otherwise an RGB image (3 bytes per pixel)
bit1 set (2): the provided image has one additional byte per pixel, as alpha channel (RGBA or greyscale+A)
pos: position of the image portion to write, defaults to [0 0]
size: size of the image portion to write, defaults to [0 0], which corresponds to [resolutionX resolutionY]

function.api-calltip: sim.setVisionSensorImg(int sensorHandle, buffer image, int options=0, int[2] pos={0, 0}, int[2] size={0, 0})

function.api-description: Acquires or releases a system-wide semaphore, i.e. across several CoppeliaSim instances
function.api-synopsis-python: sim.systemSemaphore(string key, bool acquire)
function.api-synopsis-lua: sim.systemSemaphore(string key, bool acquire)

ul.li: key: the key
acquire: whether the semaphore should be acquired or released

function.api-calltip: sim.systemSemaphore(string key, bool acquire)

function.api-description: Requests a stop of the running simulation
function.api-see-also: sim.startSimulation sim.pauseSimulation sim.getSimulationState simulation state diagram
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simStopSimulation()

ul.li: -1 in case of an error, 0 if the operation could not be performed. >0 in case of success.

function.api-synopsis-python: sim.stopSimulation(bool wait = False)
function.api-synopsis-lua: sim.stopSimulation(bool wait = false)

ul.li: wait: if true, will wait until the simulation state is sim.simulation_stopped, otherwise only triggers a stop request. If true, calling script cannot be the main- or a simulation script, and should run threaded.

function.api-calltip: sim.stopSimulation()

function.api-description: Removes an object from an OC tree, as voxel subtractions
function.api-see-also: sim.insertObjectIntoOctree sim.removeVoxelsFromOctree OC tree related functions
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simSubtractObjectFromOctree(int octreeHandle, int objectHandle, int options, void* reserved)

ul.li: octreeHandle: handle of the OC tree
objectHandle: handle of the object to subtract. Only potentially collidable objects are supported
options: reserved. Set to 0
reserved: reserved for future extensions. Set to nullptr
-1 if operation was not successful, otherwise the total number of voxels in the OC tree

function.api-synopsis-python: int totalVoxelCnt = sim.subtractObjectFromOctree(int octreeHandle, int objectHandle, int options)
function.api-synopsis-lua: int totalVoxelCnt = sim.subtractObjectFromOctree(int octreeHandle, int objectHandle, int options)

ul.li: octreeHandle: handle of the OC tree
objectHandle: handle of the object to subtract. Only potentially collidable objects are supported
options: reserved. Set to 0
totalVoxelCnt: total number of voxels in the OC tree

function.api-calltip: int totalVoxelCnt = sim.subtractObjectFromOctree(int octreeHandle, int objectHandle, int options)

function.api-description: Removes an object from a point cloud, as a subtraction
function.api-see-also: sim.insertPointsIntoPointCloud sim.insertObjectIntoPointCloud sim.removePointsFromPointCloud point cloud related functions
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simSubtractObjectFromPointCloud(int pointCloudHandle, int objectHandle, int options, double tolerance, void* reserved)

ul.li: pointCloudHandle: handle of the point cloud
objectHandle: handle of the object to subtract. Only potentially measurable objects are supported
options: reserved. Set to 0
tolerance: distance used as a tolerance value
reserved: reserved for future extensions. Set to nullptr
-1 if operation was not successful, otherwise the total number of points in the point cloud

function.api-synopsis-python: int totalPointCnt = sim.subtractObjectFromPointCloud(int pcHandle, int objectHandle, int options, float tolerance)
function.api-synopsis-lua: int totalPointCnt = sim.subtractObjectFromPointCloud(int pcHandle, int objectHandle, int options, float tolerance)

ul.li: pcHandle: handle of the point cloud
objectHandle: handle of the object to subtract. Only potentially measurable objects are supported
options: reserved. Set to 0
tolerance: distance used as a tolerance value
totalPointCnt: total number of points in the point cloud

function.api-calltip: int totalPointCnt = sim.subtractObjectFromPointCloud(int pointCloudHandle, int objectHandle, int options, float tolerance)

function.api-synopsis-lua: string text, int[2] pos, int[2] size, bool visible = sim.textEditorGetInfo(int handle)

function.api-description: Modifies a buffer than contains packed data
function.api-synopsis-python: a) bytes outBuff = sim.transformBuffer(bytes inBuff, int inFormat, float mult, float off, int outFormat) b) list outBuff = sim.transformBuffer(bytes inBuff, sim.buffer_uint8, 0, int splitSize, sim.buffer_split)
function.api-synopsis-lua: a) buffer outBuff = sim.transformBuffer(buffer inBuffer, int inFormat, float mult, float off, int outFormat) b) buffer[] outBuff = sim.transformBuffer(buffer inBuffer, sim.buffer_uint8, 0, int splitSize, sim.buffer_split)

ul.li: inBuff: input buffer that contains packed data
inFormat: buffer type
mult: multiplier value. We have out = offset + multiplier * in
off/splitSize: offset or split size value. We have out = offset + multiplier * in
outFormat: desired buffer type for the returned buffer
a) outBuff: the modified buffer
b) outBuff: the various split buffers

function.api-calltip: buffer outBuffer = sim.transformBuffer(buffer inBuffer, int inFormat, float multiplier, float offset, int outFormat)

function.api-description: Transforms an image in various ways
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simTransformImage(unsigned char* image, const int* resolution, int options, const double* floatParams, const int* intParams, void* reserved)

ul.li: image: pointer to rgb or rgba values of the image
resolution: resolution of the image

options: bit-coded:
bit0 set (1): the provided image is rgba (or a depth buffer, i.e. one double per image pixel), otherwise it is rgb
bit1 set (2): the image will be flipped on its x-axis
bit2 set (4): the image will be flipped on its y-axis
floatParams: Reserved for future extension. Set to nullptr.
intParams: Reserved for future extension. Set to nullptr.
reserved: Reserved for future extension. Set to nullptr.
-1 if operation was not successful.

function.api-synopsis-python: sim.transformImage(bytes image, list resolution, int options)
function.api-synopsis-lua: sim.transformImage(buffer image, int[2] resolution, int options)

ul.li: image: buffer to rgb or rgba values of the image
resolution: resolution of the image

options: bit-coded:
bit0 set (1): the provided image is rgba (or a depth buffer, i.e. one double per image pixel), otherwise it is rgb
bit1 set (2): the image will be flipped on its x-axis
bit2 set (4): the image will be flipped on its y-axis

function.api-calltip: sim.transformImage(buffer image, int[2] resolution, int options)

function.api-description: Multiplies a vector with a transformation matrix (v = m * v)
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simTransformVector(const double* matrix, double* vect)

ul.li: matrix: the transformation matrix: [Vx0 Vy0 Vz0 P0 Vx1 Vy1 Vz1 P1 Vx2 Vy2 Vz2 P2]
vect: the vector to be transformed (a pointer to 3 values)
-1 if operation was not successful

function.api-description: Extracts all key-value pairs from the table at the top of the stack, and removes the table
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simUnfoldStackTable(int stackHandle)

ul.li: stackHandle: stack handle obtained with simCreateStack
-1 in case of an error

function.api-description: Ungroups a compound shape into several shapes
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int* simUngroupShape(int shapeHandle, int* shapeCount)

ul.li: shapeHandle: handles of the shape you wish to ungroup. If you specify for this argument (-2-handleOfShape), then the shape will be divided instead of ungrouped
shapeCount (output): size of the returned buffer
a pointer to an array holding the handles of the resulting shapes, or nullptr in case of an error. The user is in charge of releasing the array buffer with simReleaseBuffer.

function.api-synopsis-python: list shapeHandles = sim.ungroupShape(int shapeHandle)
function.api-synopsis-lua: int[] shapeHandles = sim.ungroupShape(int shapeHandle)

ul.li: shapeHandle: handles of the shape you wish to ungroup. If you specify for this argument (-2-handleOfShape), then the shape will be divided instead of ungrouped
shapeHandles: array holding the handles of the resulting shapes

function.api-calltip: int[] simpleShapeHandles = sim.ungroupShape(int shapeHandle)

function.api-description: Unpacks a string (or part of it) into an array of double floating-point numbers
function.api-synopsis-python: list doubleNumbers = sim.unpackDoubleTable(bytes data, int startDoubleIndex = 0, int doubleCount = 0, int additionalByteOffset = 0)
function.api-synopsis-lua: float[] doubleNumbers = sim.unpackDoubleTable(buffer data, int startDoubleIndex = 0, int doubleCount = 0, int additionalByteOffset = 0)

ul.li: data: string (values between 0 and 255) that contains packed floating-point numbers
startDoubleIndex: zero-based index from which on data should be unpacked (from data[8*startDoubleIndex+1+additionalByteOffset]). Can be omitted in which case 0 is used
doubleCount: amount of doubles that should be unpacked. Can be omitted in which case 0 is used (which indicates that the maximum of doubles should be unpacked from the indicated startIndex)
additionalByteOffset: byte offset that will be added before reading the doubless. Can be omitted, in which case 0 is used.
doubleNumbers: array containing unpacked double floating-point numbers

function.api-calltip: float[] doubleNumbers = sim.unpackDoubleTable(buffer data, int startDoubleIndex=0, int doubleCount=0, int additionalByteOffset=0)

function.api-description: Unpacks a string (or part of it) into an array of floating-point numbers
function.api-synopsis-python: list floatingNumbers = sim.unpackFloatTable(bytes data, int startFloatIndex = 0, int floatCount = 0, int additionalByteOffset = 0)
function.api-synopsis-lua: float[] floatingNumbers = sim.unpackFloatTable(buffer data, int startFloatIndex = 0, int floatCount = 0, int additionalByteOffset = 0)

ul.li: data: string (values between 0 and 255) that contains packed floating-point numbers
startFloatIndex: zero-based index from which on data should be unpacked (from data[4*startFloatIndex+1+additionalByteOffset]). Can be omitted in which case 0 is used
floatCount: amount of floats that should be unpacked. Can be omitted in which case 0 is used (which indicates that the maximum of floats should be unpacked from the indicated startFloatIndex)
additionalByteOffset: byte offset that will be added before reading the floats. Can be omitted, in which case 0 is used.
floatingNumbers: array containing unpacked floating-point numbers

function.api-calltip: float[] floatNumbers = sim.unpackFloatTable(buffer data, int startFloatIndex=0, int floatCount=0, int additionalByteOffset=0)

function.api-description: Unpacks a string (or part of it) into an array of int32 numbers
function.api-synopsis-python: list int32Numbers = sim.unpackInt32Table(bytes data, int startInt32Index = 0, int int32Count = 0, int additionalByteOffset = 0)
function.api-synopsis-lua: int[] int32Numbers = sim.unpackInt32Table(buffer data, int startInt32Index = 0, int int32Count = 0, int additionalByteOffset = 0)

ul.li: data: string (values between 0 and 255) that contains packed int32 numbers
startInt32Index: zero-based index from which on data should be unpacked (from data[4*startInt32Index+1+additionalByteOffset]). Can be omitted in which case 0 is used
int32Count: amount of int32s that should be unpacked. Can be omitted in which case 0 is used (which indicates that the maximum of int32s should be unpacked from the indicated startInt32Index)
additionalByteOffset: byte offset that will be added before reading the int32s. Can be omitted, in which case 0 is used.
int32Numbers: array containing unpacked int32 numbers

function.api-calltip: int[] int32Numbers = sim.unpackInt32Table(buffer data, int startInt32Index=0, int int32Count=0, int additionalByteOffset=0)

function.api-description: Unpacks a buffer into a table
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simUnpackTable(int stackHandle, const char* buffer, int bufferSize)

ul.li: stackHandle: stack handle obtained with simCreateStack. The unpacked table will be pushed onto the stack.
buffer: packed table (buffer)
bufferSize: size of the buffer
-1 in case of an error.

function.api-synopsis-python: list/dict aTable = sim.unpackTable(bytes buffer)
function.api-synopsis-lua: any[]/map aTable = sim.unpackTable(buffer buffer)

ul.li: buffer: an input buffer
aTable: the unpacked buffer

function.api-calltip: any aTable = sim.unpackTable(buffer buffer)

function.api-description: Unpacks a string (or part of it) into an array of uint16 numbers
function.api-synopsis-python: list uint16Numbers = sim.unpackUInt16Table(bytes data, int starUint16Index = 0, int uint16Count = 0, int additionalByteOffset)
function.api-synopsis-lua: int[] uint16Numbers = sim.unpackUInt16Table(buffer data, int starUint16Index = 0, int uint16Count = 0, int additionalByteOffset)

ul.li: data: string (values between 0 and 255) that contains packed uint16 numbers
starUint16Index: zero-based index from which on data should be unpacked (from data[2*starUint16Index+1+additionalByteOffset]). Can be omitted in which case 0 is used.
uint16Count: amount of uint16s that should be unpacked. Can be omitted in which case 0 is used (which indicates that the maximum of uint16s should be unpacked from the indicated starUint16Index).
additionalByteOffset: byte offset that will be added before reading the uint16s. Can be omitted, in which case 0 is used.
uint16Numbers: array containing unpacked uint16 numbers

function.api-calltip: int[] uint16Numbers = sim.unpackUInt16Table(buffer data, int startUint16Index=0, int uint16Count=0, int additionalByteOffset=0)

function.api-description: Unpacks a string (or part of it) into an array of uint32 numbers
function.api-synopsis-python: list uint32Numbers = sim.unpackUInt32Table(bytes data, int startUint32Index = 0, int uint32Count = 0, int additionalByteOffset = 0)
function.api-synopsis-lua: int[] uint32Numbers = sim.unpackUInt32Table(buffer data, int startUint32Index = 0, int uint32Count = 0, int additionalByteOffset = 0)

ul.li: data: string (values between 0 and 255) that contains packed uint32 numbers
startUint32Index: zero-based index from which on data should be unpacked (from data[4*startUint32Index+1+additionalByteOffset]). Can be omitted in which case 0 is used
uint32Count: amount of uint32s that should be unpacked. Can be omitted in which case 0 is used (which indicates that the maximum of uint32s should be unpacked from the indicated startUint32Index)
additionalByteOffset: byte offset that will be added before reading the uint32s. Can be omitted, in which case 0 is used.
integerNumbers: array containing unpacked uint32 numbers

function.api-calltip: int[] uint32Numbers = sim.unpackUInt32Table(buffer data, int startUint32Index=0, int uint32Count=0, int additionalByteOffset=0)

function.api-description: Unpacks a string (or part of it) into an array of uint8 numbers
function.api-synopsis-python: list uint8Numbers = sim.unpackUInt8Table(bytes data, int startUint8Index = 0, int uint8Count = 0)
function.api-synopsis-lua: int[] uint8Numbers = sim.unpackUInt8Table(buffer data, int startUint8Index = 0, int uint8Count = 0)

ul.li: data: string (values between 0 and 255) that contains uint8 numbers
startUint8Index: zero-based index from which on data should be unpacked (from data[startUint8Index]). Can be omitted in which case 0 is used.
uint8Count: amount of uint8s that should be unpacked. Can be omitted in which case 0 is used (which indicates that the maximum of uint8s should be unpacked from the indicated startUint8Index).

function.api-description: Waits for a certain amount of time
function.api-synopsis-python: float deltaTimeLeft = sim.wait(float deltaTime, bool simulationTime = True)
function.api-synopsis-lua: float deltaTimeLeft = sim.wait(float deltaTime, bool simulationTime = true)

ul.li: deltaTime: minimum time duration to wait
simulationTime: indicates whether we want to wait in terms of simulation- or real-time

deltaTimeLeft: "wait resolution" of this function is the simulation time step, and the sim.wait command may overshoot the requested waiting time. deltaTimeLeft is the negative overshoot time. If the function was called at simulation time X, and the function returned at simulation time Y, then deltaTimeLeft is deltaTime-(Y-X). deltaTimeLeft is also memorized internally on a thread-basis and used as compensation or correction factor in subsequent blocking commands. deltaTimeLeft is 0 if the simulationTime argument was false

function.api-calltip: float timeLeft = sim.wait(float dt, bool simulationTime=true)

function.api-description: Overwrites a specific texture (or a portion of it) with RGB data
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simWriteTexture(int textureId, int options, const char* textureData, int posX, int posY, int sizeX, int sizeY, double interpolation)

ul.li: textureId: ID of the texture. See also simGetTextureId

options: bit-coded:
bit0 reserved. Do not set
bit1 reserved. Do not set
bit2 set (4)=only an elliptical/circular portion of the texture data will be written
textureData: RGB data to write onto the texture. Each pixel is represented with 3 bytes (0-255)
posX / posY: x/y position where to copy the RGB data. Set to 0/0 to overwrite the full texture
sizeX / sizeY: x/y size of the RGB data. Set to 0/0 to overwrite the full texture
interpolation: fade or interpolation factor. 0 for no fade
-1 in case of an error.

function.api-synopsis-python: sim.writeTexture(int textureId, int options, bytes textureData, int posX = 0, int posY = 0, int sizeX = 0, int sizeY = 0, float interpolation = 0)
function.api-synopsis-lua: sim.writeTexture(int textureId, int options, buffer textureData, int posX = 0, int posY = 0, int sizeX = 0, int sizeY = 0, float interpolation = 0)

ul.li: textureId: ID of the texture. See also sim.getTextureId

options: bit-coded:
bit0 reserved. Do not set
bit1 reserved. Do not set
bit2 set (4)=only an elliptical/circular portion of the texture data will be written
textureData: RGB data to write onto the texture. Each pixel is represented with 3 bytes (0-255)
posX / posY: x/y position where to copy the RGB data. Set to 0/0 to overwrite the full texture
sizeX / sizeY: x/y size of the RGB data. Set to 0/0 to overwrite the full texture
interpolation: fade or interpolation factor. 0 for no fade

function.api-calltip: sim.writeTexture(int textureId, int options, buffer textureData, int posX=0, int posY=0, int sizeX=0, int sizeY=0, float interpol=0.0)

function.api-description: Fetches the name of a property, based on an index
function.api-synopsis-cpp: char* simGetPropertyName(long long target, int index, SPropertyOptions* options)

function.api-synopsis-lua: string propertyName = sim.getPropertyName(int target, int index, map options = {})

propertyName: property name

function.api-description: Fetches information about a specific property
function.api-synopsis-cpp: int simGetPropertyInfo(long long target, const char* propertyName, SPropertyInfo* infos, SPropertyOptions* options)

ul.li: target: target item
propertyName: property name
infos: information about the property (e.g. type, flags, description)
options: options, can be nullptr
1 in case of success

function.api-synopsis-python: int type, int flags, string description = sim.getPropertyInfo(int target, string propertyName, dict options = {})
function.api-synopsis-lua: int type, int flags, string description = sim.getPropertyInfo(int target, string propertyName, map options = {})

ul.li: target: target item
propertyName: property name
options: an optional map. Set options.shortInfoTxt to true to fetch a short version of the description text
type: property type
flags: property flags
description: property description
